summary: This document is a legal submission from Kirkland & Ellis LLP to the Office of the Deputy Attorney General, arguing against federal prosecution of Jeffrey Epstein. It contends Epstein's conduct (soliciting massages that sometimes involved sexual activity) was a state-level misdemeanor, not a federal crime under statutes 18 U.S.C. §§ 1591, 2422(b), or 2423(b). The submission cites Supreme Court rulings on statutory interpretation, argues the lack of interstate nexus, and claims victims lied about their ages. It requests the DOJ end federal involvement and let Florida handle the case.

persons.name: Jeffrey E. Epstein
persons.context: The central subject of the legal submission. Described as a successful businessman and philanthropist with no prior criminal record, accused of soliciting prostitution from women, some of whom were minors. His defense argues his conduct was a local state crime, not a federal offense.

persons.name: Justice Scalia
persons.context: Author of the plurality opinion in United States v. Santos, cited to support the argument for narrow construction of federal criminal statutes and the rule of lenity.

persons.name: Justice Thomas
persons.context: Author of a Supreme Court decision (alongside Scalia's) cited as revitalizing principles of narrow construction for federal criminal statutes.

persons.name: Justice Stevens
persons.context: Cited for his concurring opinion in United States v. Santos, acknowledging the rule of lenity.

persons.name: Justice Alito
persons.context: Cited for his concurring opinion in Cuellar v. United States, emphasizing the need to prove the defendant's purpose, not just the effect, of an action.

persons.name: Brian Benczkowski
persons.context: Author of a 2007 Justice Department letter cited to argue that prostitution-related offenses have historically been prosecuted at the state level, not federally.

persons.name: Walter Dellinger
persons.context: Author of a 1994 memorandum cited on Presidential authority and the Executive Branch's obligation not to exceed its legal authority.

persons.name: Abner J. Mikva
persons.context: Recipient of the 1994 memorandum from Walter Dellinger on executive authority, cited in the submission.

persons.name: Barry Kutun
persons.context: Referenced as a similar but more egregious local Florida case where the defendant pleaded guilty to state charges involving underage prostitutes, with federal prosecutors declining to get involved. Used to argue against disparate treatment of Epstein.

connections.description: Epstein's defense cites Scalia's opinion in United States v. Santos to argue for narrow construction of federal statutes, attempting to shield Epstein from prosecution.
The submission compares Epstein's case to Kutun's, arguing Kutun's more egregious conduct was handled solely by the state, so Epstein should not face federal charges.
Dellinger authored a memorandum to Mikva on Presidential authority, which is cited in the submission to argue the Executive Branch must not exceed its legal bounds.

events.title: Supreme Court Decisions in Santos and Cuellar
events.description: The Supreme Court issued decisions in United States v. Santos and Cuellar v. United States, emphasizing narrow construction of federal criminal statutes and the rule of lenity. These rulings are central to the defense's argument against prosecuting Epstein under federal law.

events.title: DOJ Letter on Prostitution Prosecutions
events.description: Principal Deputy Assistant Attorney General Brian Benczkowski wrote a letter to the House Committee on the Judiciary stating prostitution-related offenses have historically been prosecuted at the state level and federal jurisdiction is not necessary.

events.title: Barry Kutun Plea Agreement
events.description: Former North Miami city attorney Barry Kutun pleaded guilty in a Miami-Dade County courtroom to state charges related to having sex with underage prostitutes. He received probation, and federal prosecutors declined to get involved.

events.title: Cut-off Date for State Statute of Limitations
events.description: The submission argues that almost all alleged conduct in the federal investigation occurred prior to June 20, 2005, meaning Florida's statute of limitations (1 year for misdemeanors, 3 years for felonies) would bar state prosecution, which in turn negates a required element of the federal statute 18 U.S.C. § 2422(b).

events.title: Death of Epstein's Mother
events.description: Mentioned in the context of Epstein's reasons for being in Florida, to visit his hospitalized and convalescing mother until her death in April 2004.

locations: Mr. Epstein's home in Palm Beach, Florida
keyFacts: The document is a defense submission arguing Jeffrey Epstein's alleged conduct (soliciting massages that sometimes involved sexual activity) is a state misdemeanor, not a federal crime under statutes 1591, 2422(b), or 2423(b).
It claims Epstein did not use interstate facilities (phone, internet) to knowingly induce minors, did not travel for the purpose of sex with minors, and did not engage in sex trafficking or coercion.
It asserts that many of the women who were underage lied to Epstein about their age, and that all sexual activity was consensual and unplanned.
The defense cites Supreme Court cases (Santos, Cuellar) to argue for narrow construction of federal statutes and the 'rule of lenity,' and the DOJ's 'Petite Policy' against successive prosecutions.
It references a similar Florida case (Barry Kutun) where federal prosecutors declined to get involved, arguing Epstein should not be treated differently.
